item.title: SURAKSHA 1.3
item.dc:creator: lucidadmin
item.content:encoded:
determine broad health concerns and pre-empt and serious disorders.

What's Included

  • Complete Blood Picture
  • Erythrocyte Sedimentation Rate  (ESR)
  • Glucose, Fasting (FBS)
  • Glycosylated Hb (HbA1C)
  • Total Bilirubin
  • Direct Bilirubin
  • Indirect Bilirubin
  • ALT (SGPT)
  • AST (SGOT)
  • Alkaline Phsophatase
  • Total Protein
  • Albumin
  • Globulin
  • A/G Ratio
  • Total Cholesterol
  • HDL Cholesterol
  • LDL Cholesterol
  • VLDL Cholesterol
  • Triglycerides
  • Chol/HDL Ratio
  • LDL/HDL Ratio
  • Non-HDL Cholesterol
  • Urea, Serum
  • Creatinine, Serum
  • Uric Acid, Serum
  • Calcium, Serum
  • Electrolytes, Serum
  • Transferrin Saturation
  • Iron with TIBC
  • Rheumatoid Factor (RA Factor)
  • Vitamin B12 (Cyanocobalamine),Serum
  • 25 Hydroxy Vitamin D

What is Suraksha 1.3 Check-up?
Suraksha 1.3 is a customized health check-up that is designed to help your doctor determine broad health concerns and pre-empt and serious disorders. The check-up is useful for identifying blood-related conditions, kidney and liver functioning, heart conditions and so on. The tests prescribed under the package help you diagnose serious health conditions early and take necessary preventive measures.

Who is advised to undergo Suraksha 1.3 Check-up?
All adults, across every age group and both genders can benefit from a Suraksha 1.3 Health Check-up. This will help diagnose and determine serious health ailment of the heart, lungs, kidneys and liver, besides any other health conditions. The results can be helpful in altering the lifestyle habits of the patients such that more serious health complications can be prevented in the long-run.

Preparing for the Suraksha 1.3 Check-up
The Suraksha 1.3 check-up will require you to give a sample of blood. The blood samples must be provided on an empty stomach and will be used for CBP, Lipid Profile, ESR, LFT and other tests included in the package.

IMPORTANT

  • Experts Advice: Once every 12 month
  • Avoid eating the night prior to the test
  • advised for all working adults and elderly individuals
  • Leave any jewellery at home

Time For All Tests

  • Half a Day, Depending on the clinic’s state

item.title: SURAKSHA 1.2
item.dc:creator: lucidadmin
item.content:encoded:
Determine broad health concerns and pre-empt and serious disorders.

What is included

  • Complete Blood Picture
  • Glucose, Fasting (FBS)
  • Total Bilirubin
  • Direct Bilirubin
  • Indirect Bilirubin
  • ALT (SGPT)
  • AST (SGOT)
  • Alkaline Phsophatase
  • Total Protein
  • Albumin
  • Globulin
  • A/G Ratio
  • Total Cholesterol
  • HDL Cholesterol
  • LDL Cholesterol
  • VLDL Cholesterol
  • Triglycerides
  • Chol/HDL Ratio
  • LDL/HDL Ratio
  • Non-HDL Cholesterol
  • Creatinine, Serum
  • Urea, Serum
  • Uric Acid, Serum
  • Calcium, Serum
  • Thyroid Stimulating Hormone (TSH)
  • Triidothyronine, Total (T3)
  • Thyroxine, Total (T4)
  • Vitamin B12 (Cyanocobalamine),Serum
  • 25 Hydroxy Vitamin D

What is Suraksha 1.2 Check-up?
Suraksha 1.2 is a customized health check-up that is designed to help your doctor determine if you are suffering from any blood-related disorders such as – anaemia, leukaemia and other infections; in addition to vitamin deficiencies, if any. The check-up also helps determine disorders of the kidneys and liver-related problems. All tests undertaken as part of the Suraksha 1.2 Health Check-up help detect bone-related disorders, kidney and liver disorders. The check-up also offers an insight into the working of the thyroid gland.

Who is advised to undergo Suraksha 1.2 Check-up?
A Suraksha 1.2 Health check-up is designed for all adults – across age groups and genders – to determine liver, kidney, bone, and vitamin deficiency disorders. This check-up is specially prescribed and advised for patients with a kidney, liver or thyroid-related conditions. Results allow the patients to remain well informed of any short or long-term liver, kidney and bone related health issues and thereby allows for preventive care.

Preparing for the Suraksha 1.2 Check-up
For Suraksha 1.2 check-up you will be required to give a sample of blood. The blood samples must be provided on an empty stomach. The blood sample will be used for CBP, Lipid Profile, LFT and other tests included in the package.

Blood samples are also taken for ALT and AST tests. This will also test serum bilirubin, serum calcium and other indices to understand the working of the liver.

IMPORTANT

  • Experts Advice: Once every 12 month
  • Avoid eating the night prior to the test
  • advised for all working adults and elderly individuals
  • Leave any jewellery at home

Time For All Tests

  • Half a Day, Depending on the clinic’s state

item.title: Master Health Check-up
item.dc:creator: lucidadmin
item.content:encoded:
Get your overall health & wellness check-up

What is a Master Health Check-up?
A comprehensive health check to ascertain the overall health & wellness of an individual. Evaluating the vital health parameters, the master health check-up gives you a 360-degree view of your present health condition. Identifying any long or short-term health complications, the master health check-up allows your physician to help you make necessary changes in your diet or lifestyle to prevent future health problems.

Who is advised to undergo a Master Health Check-up?
A master health check is advised for adults of all age groups at least once in a year. This keeps you well informed of any short or long-term health issues and allows for preventive care before any health condition can become serious and threatening.

Preparing for the Master Health Check-up
For a master health check-up you will be required to give a sample of blood and urine. The blood samples must be provided on an empty stomach. The blood sample will be used for CBP, Lipid Profile, ESR, LFT and other tests included in the package. For CUE and Creatinine tests you will provide a urine sample.

For the abdominal ultrasound, you must avoid eating the night prior to the test and leave any jewellery at home. The package also includes a chest x-ray and an ECG – for the ECG it is best to avoid usage of moisturisers or sunscreen on the body and jewellery must be removed. For the x-ray similar protocols as above must be followed.

What's Included

Complete blood picture measures the count of WBCs, RBCs and platelets in the blood and indicates any deficiencies. This test helps ascertain the overall health profile of an individual.
Lipid profile ascertains the total levels of cholesterol, HDL cholesterol, LDL cholesterol, triglycerides in the blood streams to assess the cardiac health of an individual.
The erythrocyte sedimentation rate test is used to determine inflammation associated with conditions such as infections, cancers, and autoimmune diseases in the body.
Liver function tests are employed to understand the working of the liver and include prothrombin time (PT/INR), aPTT, albumin, bilirubin (direct and indirect), and others.
A complete urine examination evaluates a sample of the urine to determine disorders such as urinary tract infection, kidney diseases and diabetes related complications.
A thyroid stimulating hormone test determines the levels of the hormone in the body. Excessive or deficient secretion are both detrimental to the health and this tests helps ascertain the same.
A fasting glucose test determines the sugar levels in the blood stream following an eight-hour fasting period. This is typically conducted early in the morning hours prior to breakfast.
A HBA1C test is also known as haemoglobin A1c or glycated haemoglobin test. It gives an indication of the sugar levels in the body and is an important determinant of diabetes control.
The blood urea nitrogen test determines the functioning of the kidneys. Blood urea nitrogen is a waste product generated by the body and its level indicate the abnormalities in the kidneys, if any.
A creatinine blood test determines creatinine levels in the body which in turn indicates disorders of the kidneys, if any. High levels of creatinine in the body is an indicator of impaired kidney function.
An electrocardiogram (ECG) measures the electrical activity of the heart. This is an indicator of the normal condition of the heart or of the possible disorders in the heart rhythm.
A chest x-ray is taken to ascertain the condition of the lungs and heart. It detects abnormalities or diseases in the heart, lungs, airways, blood vessels and the bones of the spine and chest cavity.
An ultrasound of the abdominal region is taken to determine the functioning and abnormalities, if any of the abdomen. This cover various organs like – stomach, intestines, gallbladder, spleen, pancreas and liver.
Physician Consultation

Typically, a master health check-up can be concluded in one half of the day.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Identify any long-term and short-term health complications. Physician's suggests on necessary changes in your diet or lifestyle to prevent future health problems.

item.title: Basic Heart Check-up
item.dc:creator: lucidadmin
item.content:encoded:
the exact working of your heart and possible ailments of the cardiac system.

What is included

  • 15 Tests &
  • Physician Consultation.

What is a Basic Heart Check-up?
A basic heart check-up is designed to help your doctor determine the exact working of your heart and possible ailments of the cardiac system. A comprehensive set of tests determine any abnormalities and can help in devising an appropriate treatment plan. Basic heart check-up gives your cardiologist an overall understanding of the functioning of your heart and possible cardiac complications that may arise in future.

Who is advised to undergo a Basic Heart Check-up?
A basic heart check is advised for all working adults and elderly individuals – across all age groups at least once in a year. This keeps you well informed of any short or long-term cardiac health issues and allows for preventive care before any of them can become serious and threatening.

Preparing for a Basic Heart Check-up
For the basic heart check-up you will be required to give a sample of blood and urine. The blood samples must be provided on an empty stomach. The blood sample will be used for CBP, Lipid Profile, ESR, LFT and other tests included in the package. For CUE and Creatinine tests you will provide a urine sample.

For the abdominal ultrasound, you must avoid eating the night prior to the test and leave any jewellery at home. A 2d echo is also an ultrasound procedure requiring similar precautions.
The package also includes a chest x-ray and an ECG – for the ECG it is best to avoid usage of moisturisers or sunscreen on the body and jewellery must be removed. For the x-ray similar protocols as above must be followed.

For the TMT stress test, it is best to avoid eating prior to the test, talk to your doctor about the medications you will need to take.

Typically, a basic heart check-up can be concluded in half a day.

Complete blood picture measures the count of WBCs, RBCs and platelets in the blood and indicates any deficiencies. This test helps ascertain the overall health profile of an individual.
Liver function tests are employed to understand the working of the liver and include prothrombin time (PT/INR), aPTT, albumin, bilirubin (direct and indirect), and others.
The erythrocyte sedimentation rate test is used to determine inflammation associated with conditions such as infections, cancers, and autoimmune diseases in the body.
This is a blood test carried out to check homocysteine levels in the blood steam. Higher levels of homocysteine is associated with heart attack, stroke, and blood clots.
A complete urine examination evaluates a sample of the urine to determine disorders such as urinary tract infection, kidney diseases and diabetes related complications.
A fasting glucose test determines the sugar levels in the blood stream following an eight-hour fasting period. This is typically conducted early in the morning hours prior to breakfast.
A creatinine blood test determines creatinine levels in the body which in turn indicates disorders of the kidneys, if any. High levels of creatinine in the body is an indicator of impaired kidney function.
Lipid profile ascertains the total levels of cholesterol, HDL cholesterol, LDL cholesterol, triglycerides in the blood streams to assess the cardiac health of an individual.
A high sensitivity C-reactive protein increases in the blood stream following certain heart conditions. A test for HS CRP checks for inflammation & possible risk of certain heart conditions.
The blood urea nitrogen test determines the functioning of the kidneys. Blood urea nitrogen is a waste product generated by the body and its level indicate the abnormalities in the kidneys, if any.
A chest x-ray is taken to ascertain the condition of the lungs and heart. It detects abnormalities or diseases in the heart, lungs, airways, blood vessels and the bones of the spine and chest cavity.
An ultrasound of the abdominal region is taken to determine the functioning and abnormalities, if any of the abdomen. This cover various organs like – stomach, intestines, gallbladder, spleen, pancreas and liver.
An electrocardiogram (ECG) measures the electrical activity of the heart. This is an indicator of the normal condition of the heart or of the possible disorders in the heart rhythm.
A 2D echo tests offers the doctors a 2d images of the heart, the paracardiac structures, and the major blood vessels. The image is generated by passing sound waves through the heart.
A treadmill stress test assesses a patient’s blood circulation when he is at rest and then compares it to similar tests under optimal physical pressure.
Cardiologist Consultation

  • 15 Tests
  • 1 Specialist Consultancy

Experts Advice:
  • Once every 12 months

item.title: Whole Body Health Check-up Male
item.dc:creator: lucidadmin
item.content:encoded:
Advisable for individuals who haven’t had a regular check-up for a very long time

What’s Included

  • 39 Tests &
  • Physician Consultation

What is a Whole Body Health Check-up?
A whole-body health check-up is an in-depth health check for men to ascertain the overall health & wellness. Going further than just a simple evaluation, the whole body health check-up gives you an in-depth understanding of the functioning of your various organs and their present state. Co-related with a physical examination, doctors can make informed decisions on the possible health threats and suggest appropriate changes to your lifestyle and diet.

Who is advised to undergo a Whole Body Health Check-up?
This is especially advised for those who haven’t had a regular check-up for a very long time. The test keeps you well informed of any short or long-term health issues and allows for preventive care before any health condition can become serious and threatening.

Preparing for the Whole Body Health Check-up
For the whole body health check-up you will be required to give a sample of blood and urine. The blood samples must be provided on an empty stomach. The blood sample will be used for CBP, Lipid Profile, ESR, LFT and other tests included in the package. For CUE and Creatinine tests you will provide a urine sample.

For the abdominal ultrasound, you must avoid eating the night prior to the test and leave any jewellery at home. A 2d echo is also an ultrasound procedure requiring similar precautions.
The package also includes a chest x-ray and an ECG – for the ECG it is best to avoid usage of moisturisers or sunscreen on the body and jewellery must be removed. For the x-ray similar protocols as above must be followed.

A bone mineral density test is similar to an x-ray and the same precautions will suffice.
For the brain CT scan, the precautions are the same as the x-ray.

A PSA is undertaken which will be ascertained with the same blood sample.

What tests are carried out, as part of the Whole Body Health Check-up?

Package includes

Complete blood picture measures the count of WBCs, RBCs and platelets in the blood and indicates any deficiencies. This test helps ascertain the overall health profile of an individual.
A thyroid stimulating hormone test determines the levels of the hormone in the body. Excessive or deficient secretion are both detrimental to the health and this tests helps ascertain the same.
The erythrocyte sedimentation rate test is used to determine inflammation associated with conditions such as infections, cancers, and autoimmune diseases in the body.
A complete urine examination evaluates a sample of the urine to determine disorders such as urinary tract infection, kidney diseases and diabetes related complications.
Vitamin D levels in the body are determined by a blood test. The test measures the levels of 25-hydroxyvitamin D and/or 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D in the blood to determine deficiency or excess of the vitamin.
A HBA1C test is also known as haemoglobin A1c or glycated haemoglobin test. It gives an indication of the sugar levels in the body and is an important determinant of diabetes control.
A fasting glucose test determines the sugar levels in the blood stream following an eight-hour fasting period. This is typically conducted early in the morning hours prior to breakfast.
This is a test to determine a patient’s infection with Hepatitis B virus. A sample of blood is taken and tested for hepatitis B surface antigen – a positive test means the patient is infected with the Hepatitis B virus.
Liver function tests are employed to understand the working of the liver and include prothrombin time (PT/INR), aPTT, albumin, bilirubin (direct and indirect), and others.
The blood urea nitrogen test determines the functioning of the kidneys. Blood urea nitrogen is a waste product generated by the body and its level indicate the abnormalities in the kidneys, if any.
Calcium & uric acid test is undertaken to test for kidney stones. Excessive calcium and uric acid in the blood stream is an indicator of the presence of kidney stones in an individual.
A creatinine blood test determines creatinine levels in the body which in turn indicates disorders of the kidneys, if any. High levels of creatinine in the body is an indicator of impaired kidney function.
Lipid profile ascertains the total levels of cholesterol, HDL cholesterol, LDL cholesterol, triglycerides in the blood streams to assess the cardiac health of an individual.
An electrolyte test determines the levels of sodium, potassium, chloride, and bicarbonate. Imbalances of these minerals can cause dehydration, kidney or lung complications amongst others.
A 2D echo tests offers the doctors a 2d images of the heart, the paracardiac structures, and the major blood vessels. The image is generated by passing sound waves through the heart.
Calcium & uric acid test is undertaken to test for kidney stones. Excessive calcium and uric acid in the blood stream is an indicator of the presence of kidney stones in an individual.
A bone mineral density test is undertaken to determine the strength of the spine. It measures how much calcium and other types of minerals are present in the spine at a particular location of the body.
An electrocardiogram (ECG) measures the electrical activity of the heart. This is an indicator of the normal condition of the heart or of the possible disorders in the heart rhythm.
A chest x-ray is taken to ascertain the condition of the lungs and heart. It detects abnormalities or diseases in the heart, lungs, airways, blood vessels and the bones of the spine and chest cavity.
An ultrasound of the abdominal region is taken to determine the functioning and abnormalities, if any of the abdomen. This cover various organs like – stomach, intestines, gallbladder, spleen, pancreas and liver.
A computed tomography of the brain is an imaging technology employed to check for internal head injuries or disorders. A CT Scan of the brain helps ascertain aneurysm, bleeding, strokes and others.
The total PSA test measures the levels of prostate specific antigens in the blood stream of a patient. It is an indicator of the onset of prostate cancer.
A test undertaken to detect the presence of blood in stool that is invisible to the naked eye. Internal bleeding of the gastrointestinal tract could lead to bleeding in stools, detected by this test.
Physician Consultation

IMPORTANT

  • Avoid eating the night prior to the test
  • Leave any jewellery at home

Time For All Tests

  • A Complete Day, Depending on the clinic’s state

Experts Advice:
  • Once every 12 months

item.title: Executive Check-up Female
item.dc:creator: lucidadmin
item.content:encoded:
A 360-degree view of your present health condition. women-specific health check-up.

What is included

  • 38 Test &
  • Physician Consultation

Scroll down for detailed list

What is an Executive Health Check-up for Women?
This is a comprehensive health check for working women to ascertain the overall health & wellness. The female health check-up gives you a 360-degree view of your present health condition with an emphasis on women-specific health complications. Along with a physical examination, your doctor can recommend specific dietary and lifestyle-related modifications to ensure any major health complication of the future can be sufficiently prevented.

Who is advised to undergo an Executive Health Check-up for Women?
An executive health check for women is advised for all women above the age of 18; This keeps you well informed of any short or long-term health issues and allows for preventive care before any health condition can become serious and threatening.

Preparing for the Executive Health Check-up – Women
For an executive health check-up for women, you will be required to give a sample of blood and urine. The blood samples must be provided on an empty stomach. The blood sample will be used for CBP, Lipid Profile, ESR, LFT, Vitamin D and other tests included in the package. For CUE and Creatinine tests you will provide a urine sample.

For the abdominal ultrasound, you must avoid eating the night prior to the test and leave any jewellery at home. The package also includes a chest x-ray and an ECG – for the ECG it is best to avoid usage of moisturisers or sunscreen on the body and jewellery must be removed. For the x-ray similar protocols as above must be followed. A mammogram is an x-ray of the breasts and it is best to schedule one right after your menstrual cycle. It is best to avoid sprays, creams and gels on the breasts prior to the mammogram.

A bone mineral density test is similar to an x-ray and the same precautions will suffice.
As part of the executive health check-up for women you will need to provide a pap smear for which it is advisable to abstain from intercourse the previous night and avoid usage of a vaginal cream, gel etc., also scheduling a pap smear must be avoided during a menstrual cycle.

Typically, an executive health check-up can be concluded in one half of the day but will require careful scheduling based on your monthly cycle.

Complete blood picture measures the count of WBCs, RBCs and platelets in the blood and indicates any deficiencies. This test helps ascertain the overall health profile of an individual.
A thyroid stimulating hormone test determines the levels of the hormone in the body. Excessive or deficient secretion are both detrimental to the health and this tests helps ascertain the same.
The erythrocyte sedimentation rate test is used to determine inflammation associated with conditions such as infections, cancers, and autoimmune diseases in the body.
Vitamin D levels in the body are determined by a blood test. The test measures the levels of 25-hydroxyvitamin D and/or 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D in the blood to determine deficiency or excess of the vitamin.
A complete urine examination evaluates a sample of the urine to determine disorders such as urinary tract infection, kidney diseases and diabetes related complications.
This is a test to determine a patient’s infection with Hepatitis B virus. A sample of blood is taken and tested for hepatitis B surface antigen – a positive test means the patient is infected with the Hepatitis B virus.
Calcium & uric acid test is undertaken to test for kidney stones. Excessive calcium and uric acid in the blood stream is an indicator of the presence of kidney stones in an individual.
A fasting glucose test determines the sugar levels in the blood stream following an eight-hour fasting period. This is typically conducted early in the morning hours prior to breakfast.
A HBA1C test is also known as haemoglobin A1c or glycated haemoglobin test. It gives an indication of the sugar levels in the body and is an important determinant of diabetes control.
The blood urea nitrogen test determines the functioning of the kidneys. Blood urea nitrogen is a waste product generated by the body and its level indicate the abnormalities in the kidneys, if any.
A pulmonary function test is carried out to ascertain the functioning of the lungs and the respiratory system. It assesses organs such has the lungs, trachea, air passages and others.
A creatinine blood test determines creatinine levels in the body which in turn indicates disorders of the kidneys, if any. High levels of creatinine in the body is an indicator of impaired kidney function.
Lipid profile ascertains the total levels of cholesterol, HDL cholesterol, LDL cholesterol, triglycerides in the blood streams to assess the cardiac health of an individual.
Liver function tests are employed to understand the working of the liver and include prothrombin time (PT/INR), aPTT, albumin, bilirubin (direct and indirect), and others.
A chest x-ray is taken to ascertain the condition of the lungs and heart. It detects abnormalities or diseases in the heart, lungs, airways, blood vessels and the bones of the spine and chest cavity.
An electrocardiogram (ECG) measures the electrical activity of the heart. This is an indicator of the normal condition of the heart or of the possible disorders in the heart rhythm.
An ultrasound of the abdominal region is taken to determine the functioning and abnormalities, if any of the abdomen. This cover various organs like – stomach, intestines, gallbladder, spleen, pancreas and liver.
This is a screening procedure carried out to detect cervical cancer in women. Tissue is collected from the cervix and observed under the microscope for cells that can potentially turn cancerous.
A mammogram is an imagining procedure carried out to check for changes in the breasts which are otherwise hidden from naked eyes. These changes can help detect breast cancer at an early stage.
A bone mineral density test is undertaken to determine the strength of the spine. It measures how much calcium and other types of minerals are present in the spine at a location of the body.
Physician Consultation


Package includes

IMPORTANT

  • Experts Advice: all women above the age of 18
  • Avoid eating the night prior to the test
  • Avoid eating the night prior to the test
  • Leave any jewellery at home

Time For All Tests

  • Half a Day, Depending on the clinic’s state

item.title: Executive Check-up Male
item.dc:creator: lucidadmin
item.content:encoded:
An executive health check-up for men is advised for all working adults

What is included

  • 35 Tests
  • Physician Consultation.

What is an Executive Health Check-up for Men?
An executive health check-up for men is a comprehensive health check for all men to ascertain their overall health & wellness. The check-up evaluates all the vital health parameters of male health and gives you a 360-degree view of your present health condition. With an emphasis on male-specific diseases and disorders, this check-up helps mean prevent both long & short-term health complications.

For the x-ray similar protocols as above must be followed.

Complete blood picture measures the count of WBCs, RBCs and platelets in the blood and indicates any deficiencies. This test helps ascertain the overall health profile of an individual.
A thyroid stimulating hormone test determines the levels of the hormone in the body. Excessive or deficient secretion are both detrimental to the health and this tests helps ascertain the same.
The erythrocyte sedimentation rate test is used to determine inflammation associated with conditions such as infections, cancers, and autoimmune diseases in the body.
A complete urine examination evaluates a sample of the urine to determine disorders such as urinary tract infection, kidney diseases and diabetes related complications.
Vitamin D levels in the body are determined by a blood test. The test measures the levels of 25-hydroxyvitamin D and/or 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D in the blood to determine deficiency or excess of the vitamin.
A HBA1C test is also known as haemoglobin A1c or glycated haemoglobin test. It gives an indication of the sugar levels in the body and is an important determinant of diabetes control.
A fasting glucose test determines the sugar levels in the blood stream following an eight-hour fasting period. This is typically conducted early in the morning hours prior to breakfast.
Calcium & uric acid test is undertaken to test for kidney stones. Excessive calcium and uric acid in the blood stream is an indicator of the presence of kidney stones in an individual.
The total PSA test measures the levels of prostate specific antigens in the blood stream of a patient. It is an indicator of the onset of prostate cancer.
Lipid profile ascertains the total levels of cholesterol, HDL cholesterol, LDL cholesterol, triglycerides in the blood streams to assess the cardiac health of an individual.
Liver function tests are employed to understand the working of the liver and include prothrombin time (PT/INR), aPTT, albumin, bilirubin (direct and indirect), and others.
The blood urea nitrogen test determines the functioning of the kidneys. Blood urea nitrogen is a waste product generated by the body and its level indicate the abnormalities in the kidneys, if any.
A creatinine blood test determines creatinine levels in the body which in turn indicates disorders of the kidneys, if any. High levels of creatinine in the body is an indicator of impaired kidney function.
This is a test to determine a patient’s infection with Hepatitis B virus. A sample of blood is taken and tested for hepatitis B surface antigen – a positive test means the patient is infected with the Hepatitis B virus.
A pulmonary function test is carried out to ascertain the functioning of the lungs and the respiratory system. It assesses organs such has the lungs, trachea, air passages and others.
A chest x-ray is taken to ascertain the condition of the lungs and heart. It detects abnormalities or diseases in the heart, lungs, airways, blood vessels and the bones of the spine and chest cavity.
An electrocardiogram (ECG) measures the electrical activity of the heart. This is an indicator of the normal condition of the heart or of the possible disorders in the heart rhythm.
An ultrasound of the abdominal region is taken to determine the functioning and abnormalities, if any of the abdomen. This cover various organs like – stomach, intestines, gallbladder, spleen, pancreas and liver.
Physician Consultation

IMPORTANT

  • Experts Advice: Once every 12 Month
  • Avoid eating the night prior to the test

Time For All Tests

  • Half a Day, Depending on the clinic’s state

item.title: Basic Diabetics Check-up
item.dc:creator: lucidadmin
item.content:encoded:
Quick test for Diabetics Patients.

What is included

  • 8 Tests

Scroll down for the detailed list

What is a Basic Diabetes Check-up?
A basic diabetes check-up is designed to help your doctor determine the insulin levels in your body and ascertain the causes behind it. A comprehensive set of tests determine any abnormalities and can help in devising an appropriate treatment plan for diabetes. Diabetes check-up can also detect diabetes at an early stage, which allows your physician to make an informed decision on possible changes to your diet and lifestyle.

Who is advised to undergo a Basic Diabetes Check-up?
A basic diabetes check-up is advised for all working adults and elderly individuals – across all age groups at least once in a year. This keeps you well informed of any short or long-term diabetic issues and allows for preventive care before any of them can become serious and threatening.

Preparing for a Basic Diabetic Check-up
For a basic diabetic check-up, you will be required to give a sample of blood and urine. The blood samples for all but one test must be provided on an empty stomach. The blood sample will be used for CBP, Lipid Profile, ESR, LFT and other tests included in the package. For CUE and Creatinine tests you will provide a urine sample.

For the Post Lunch Glucose test, you will need to have a meal and wait for a couple of hours before giving an additional blood sample.

Typically, a basic diabetic check-up can be concluded in 3-4 hours.

Tests Include

Complete blood picture measures the count of WBCs, RBCs and platelets in the blood and indicates any deficiencies. This test helps ascertain the overall health profile of an individual.
The blood urea nitrogen test determines the functioning of the kidneys. Blood urea nitrogen is a waste product generated by the body and its level indicate the abnormalities in the kidneys, if any.
A complete urine examination evaluates a sample of the urine to determine disorders such as urinary tract infection, kidney diseases and diabetes related complications.
A creatinine blood test determines creatinine levels in the body which in turn indicates disorders of the kidneys, if any. High levels of creatinine in the body is an indicator of impaired kidney function.
Heightened levels of Cholesterol in the body increase the risk of heart conditions. A cholesterol test is administered by taking a small sample of blood and is usually conducted along with a lipid profile.
A fasting glucose test determines the sugar levels in the blood stream following an eight-hour fasting period. This is typically conducted early in the morning hours prior to breakfast.
A post glucose test determines the sugar levels in the blood stream following an a meal. This is typically conducted two hours after a meal.
A HBA1C test is also known as haemoglobin A1c or glycated haemoglobin test. It gives an indication of the sugar levels in the body and is an important determinant of diabetes control.

IMPORTANT

  • Experts Advice: Once every 12 month
  • Avoid eating the night prior to the test
  • advised for all working adults and elderly individuals
  • Leave any jewellery at home

Time For All Tests

  • Half a Day, Depending on the clinic’s state

item.title: Whole Body Health Check-up Female
item.dc:creator: lucidadmin
item.content:encoded:
Check up

What is included

  • 40 Tests
  • Physical Consultancy

Scroll down for detailed list

What is a Whole Body Health Check-up for Women?
A whole-body health check-up is an in-depth health check for men & women to ascertain the overall health & wellness. Going further than just a simple evaluation, the whole body health check-up gives you an in-depth understanding of the functioning of your various organs and their present state. Co-related with a physical examination, doctors can make informed decisions on the possible health threats and suggest appropriate changes to your lifestyle and diet.

Who is advised to undergo a Whole Body Health Check-up?
This is especially advised for those who haven’t had a regular check-up for a very long time. The test keeps you well informed of any short or long-term health issues and allows for preventive care before any health condition can become serious and threatening.

Preparing for the Whole Body Health Check-up
For the whole body health check-up, you will be required to give a sample of blood and urine. The blood samples must be provided on an empty stomach. The blood sample will be used for CBP, Lipid Profile, ESR, LFT and other tests included in the package. For CUE and Creatinine tests you will provide a urine sample.

For the abdominal ultrasound, you must avoid eating the night prior to the test and leave any jewellery at home. A 2d echo is also an ultrasound procedure requiring similar precautions.
The package also includes a chest x-ray and an ECG – for the ECG it is best to avoid usage of moisturisers or sunscreen on the body and jewellery must be removed. For the x-ray similar protocols as above must be followed.

A bone mineral density test is similar to an x-ray and the same precautions will suffice.
For the brain CT scan, the precautions are the same as the x-ray.

As part of the whole body health check-up for women you will need to provide a pap smear for which it is advisable to abstain from intercourse the previous night and avoid usage of a vaginal cream, gel etc., also scheduling a pap smear must be avoided during a menstrual cycle. Also included for women is a mammogram is an x-ray of the breasts and it is best to schedule one right after your menstrual cycle. It is best to avoid sprays, creams and gels on the breasts prior to the mammogram.

Typically, a whole-body health check-up can be concluded in a day but will require careful scheduling based on your monthly cycle for women.

What tests are carried out, as part of the Whole Body Health Check-up?

Complete blood picture measures the count of WBCs, RBCs and platelets in the blood and indicates any deficiencies. This test helps ascertain the overall health profile of an individual.
A thyroid stimulating hormone test determines the levels of the hormone in the body. Excessive or deficient secretion are both detrimental to the health and this tests helps ascertain the same.
The erythrocyte sedimentation rate test is used to determine inflammation associated with conditions such as infections, cancers, and autoimmune diseases in the body.
A complete urine examination evaluates a sample of the urine to determine disorders such as urinary tract infection, kidney diseases and diabetes related complications.
Vitamin D levels in the body are determined by a blood test. The test measures the levels of 25-hydroxyvitamin D and/or 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D in the blood to determine deficiency or excess of the vitamin.
A HBA1C test is also known as haemoglobin A1c or glycated haemoglobin test. It gives an indication of the sugar levels in the body and is an important determinant of diabetes control.
A fasting glucose test determines the sugar levels in the blood stream following an eight-hour fasting period. This is typically conducted early in the morning hours prior to breakfast.
This is a test to determine a patient’s infection with Hepatitis B virus. A sample of blood is taken and tested for hepatitis B surface antigen – a positive test means the patient is infected with the Hepatitis B virus.
Liver function tests are employed to understand the working of the liver and include prothrombin time (PT/INR), aPTT, albumin, bilirubin (direct and indirect), and others.
The blood urea nitrogen test determines the functioning of the kidneys. Blood urea nitrogen is a waste product generated by the body and its level indicate the abnormalities in the kidneys, if any.
Calcium & uric acid test is undertaken to test for kidney stones. Excessive calcium and uric acid in the blood stream is an indicator of the presence of kidney stones in an individual.
A creatinine blood test determines creatinine levels in the body which in turn indicates disorders of the kidneys, if any. High levels of creatinine in the body is an indicator of impaired kidney function.
Lipid profile ascertains the total levels of cholesterol, HDL cholesterol, LDL cholesterol, triglycerides in the blood streams to assess the cardiac health of an individual.
An electrolyte test determines the levels of sodium, potassium, chloride, and bicarbonate. Imbalances of these minerals can cause dehydration, kidney or lung complications amongst others.
A 2D echo tests offers the doctors a 2d images of the heart, the paracardiac structures, and the major blood vessels. The image is generated by passing sound waves through the heart.
Calcium & uric acid test is undertaken to test for kidney stones. Excessive calcium and uric acid in the blood stream is an indicator of the presence of kidney stones in an individual.
A bone mineral density test is undertaken to determine the strength of the spine. It measures how much calcium and other types of minerals are present in the spine at a particular location of the body.
An electrocardiogram (ECG) measures the electrical activity of the heart. This is an indicator of the normal condition of the heart or of the possible disorders in the heart rhythm.
A chest x-ray is taken to ascertain the condition of the lungs and heart. It detects abnormalities or diseases in the heart, lungs, airways, blood vessels and the bones of the spine and chest cavity.
An ultrasound of the abdominal region is taken to determine the functioning and abnormalities, if any of the abdomen. This cover various organs like – stomach, intestines, gallbladder, spleen, pancreas and liver.
A computed tomography of the brain is an imaging technology employed to check for internal head injuries or disorders. A CT Scan of the brain helps ascertain aneurysm, bleeding, strokes and others.
A mammogram is an imagining procedure carried out to check for changes in the breasts which are otherwise hidden from naked eyes. These changes can help detect breast cancer at an early stage.
This is a screening procedure carried out to detect cervical cancer in women. Tissue is collected from the cervix and observed under the microscope for cells that can potentially turn cancerous.
A test undertaken to detect the presence of blood in stool that is invisible to the naked eye. Internal bleeding of the gastrointestinal tract could lead to bleeding in stools, detected by this test.
Physician Consultation

IMPORTANT
Experts Advice: Once every 12 month
Avoid eating the night prior to the test
advised for all working adults and elderly individuals
Leave any jewellery at home

Time For All Tests
Half a Day, Depending on the clinic’s state

item.title: Covid Profile 1
item.dc:creator: lucidadmin
item.content:encoded:
This Monsoon, Stay Healthy

What is included

  • 8 Tests
Complete blood count measures the count of WBCs, RBCs, and platelets in the blood and indicates any deficiencies. This test helps to ascertain the overall health profile of an individual.
C- reactive proteins
Ferritin
D-Dimer
Liver function tests are employed to understand the working of the liver and include albumin, bilirubin (direct and indirect), ALT, AST, ALP and albumin serum.
Lactate Dehydrogenase (LDH)
A creatinine blood test determines creatinine levels in the body which in turn indicates disorders of the kidneys, if any. High levels of creatinine in the body is an indicator of impaired kidney function.
HRCT Chest

IMPORTANT

Typically, a basic Monsoon check-up can be concluded in half a day.

item.title: Executive Check-up
item.dc:creator: lucidadmin
item.content:encoded:
An executive health check-up for men is advised for all working adults

What is included

  • 21 Lab Tests
  • 2 Radiology & Imaging Tests
  • 1 Cardiology Test
  • 1 Other Test
  • Physician Consultation.

Scroll down for detailed list

What is an Executive Health Check-up?
An executive health check-up is a comprehensive health check for women and men to ascertain their overall health & wellness. The check-up evaluates all the vital health parameters of male health and gives you a 360-degree view of your present health condition. With an emphasis on male-specific diseases and disorders, this check-up helps mean prevent both long & short-term health complications.

Who is advised to undergo an Executive Health Check-up?
An executive health check-up is advised for all working adults; across all age groups at least once in a year.

This keeps you well informed of any short or long-term health issues and allows for preventive care before any health condition can become serious and threatening.

Preparing for the Executive Health Check-up.
You will be required to give a sample of blood and urine. The blood samples must be provided on an empty stomach. The blood sample will be used for CBP, Lipid Profile, ESR, LFT and other tests included in the package. For CUE and Creatinine tests you will provide a urine sample.

For the abdominal ultrasound, you must avoid eating the night prior to the test and leave any jewellery at home. The package also includes a chest x-ray and an ECG – for the ECG it is best to avoid usage of moisturisers or sunscreen on the body and jewellery must be removed. For the x-ray similar protocols as above must be followed.

Typically, the executive health check-up can be concluded in one half of the day.

Package includes

LABORATORY TESTS

  • Complete Blood Picture with Platelet Count
  • Complete Urine Examination (CUE)
  • Erythrocyte Sedimentation Rate  (ESR)
  • Glucose, Fasting (FBS)
  • Glycosylated Hb (HbA1C)
  • HBsAg
  • Lipid Profile
  • Albumin Serum
  • Alkaline Phosphatase
  • Bilirubin (Total, Direct and Indirect) Serum
  • Gamma GT
  • Globulin Serum
  • Protein A/G Ratio Serum
  • Protein Total Serum
  • SGOT
  • SGPT
  • Creatinine, Serum
  • Urea Serum
  • Uric Acid
  • Thyroid Profile (T3 T4 TSH)
  • Vitamin D

RADIOLOGY & IMAGING TESTS

  • USG Whole Abdomen & Pelvis
  • X-Ray Chest PA

CARDIOLOGY TESTS

  • ECG

OTHER TESTS

  • Pulmonary Function Test

REPORT REVIEW

  • Physician Consultation

Important

  • Experts Advice: Once every 12 Month
  • Avoid eating the night prior to the test

Time For All Tests

  • Half a Day, Depending on the clinic’s state

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: An executive health check-up for men is advised for all working adults

item.title: Diabetic Check-up
item.dc:creator: lucidadmin
item.content:encoded:
Quick test for Diabetics Patients.

What is included

  • 11 Lab Tests
  • 1 Cardiology Test
  • Physician Consultation.

Scroll down for the detailed list

What is a Basic Diabetes Check-up?
A basic diabetes check-up is designed to help your doctor determine the insulin levels in your body and ascertain the causes behind it. A comprehensive set of tests determine any abnormalities and can help in devising an appropriate treatment plan for diabetes. Diabetes check-up can also detect diabetes at an early stage, which allows your physician to make an informed decision on possible changes to your diet and lifestyle.

Who is advised to undergo a Basic Diabetes Check-up?
A basic diabetes check-up is advised for all working adults and elderly individuals – across all age groups at least once in a year. This keeps you well informed of any short or long-term diabetic issues and allows for preventive care before any of them can become serious and threatening.

Preparing for a Basic Diabetic Check-up
For a basic diabetic check-up, you will be required to give a sample of blood and urine. The blood samples for all but one test must be provided on an empty stomach. The blood sample will be used for CBP, Lipid Profile, ESR, LFT and other tests included in the package. For CUE and Creatinine tests you will provide a urine sample.

For the Post Lunch Glucose test, you will need to have a meal and wait for a couple of hours before giving an additional blood sample.

Typically, a basic diabetic check-up can be concluded in 3-4 hours.

Package Includes

LABORATORY TESTS

  • Complete Blood Picture with Platelet Count
  • Complete Urine Examination (CUE)
  • Glucose, Fasting (FBS)
  • Glucose, Post Lunch (PLBS)
  • Glycosylated Hb (HbA1C)
  • Lipid Profile
  • SGOT
  • SGPT
  • Creatinine Serum
  • Urea Serum
  • Microalbumin Urine

CARDIOLOGY TESTS

  • ECG

REPORT REVIEW

  • Physician Consultation

Important

  • Experts Advice: Once every 12 month
  • Avoid eating the night prior to the test
  • advised for all working adults and elderly individuals
  • Leave any jewellery at home

Time For All Tests

  • Half a Day, Depending on the clinic’s state

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Designed to help your doctor determine the insulin levels in your body and ascertain the causes behind it.

item.title: Whole Body Health Check-up
item.dc:creator: lucidadmin
item.content:encoded:
What is included

  • 22 Lab Tests
  • 4 Radiology Tests
  • 2 Cardiology Test
  • Physician Consultation

Scroll down for detailed list

What is a Whole Body Health Check-up?
A whole-body health check-up is an in-depth health check for men & women to ascertain the overall health & wellness. Going further than just a simple evaluation, the whole body health check-up gives you an in-depth understanding of the functioning of your various organs and their present state. Co-related with a physical examination, doctors can make informed decisions on the possible health threats and suggest appropriate changes to your lifestyle and diet.

Who is advised to undergo a Whole Body Health Check-up?
This is especially advised for those who haven’t had a regular check-up for a very long time. The test keeps you well informed of any short or long-term health issues and allows for preventive care before any health condition can become serious and threatening.

Preparing for the Whole Body Health Check-up
For the whole body health check-up, you will be required to give a sample of blood and urine. The blood samples must be provided on an empty stomach. The blood sample will be used for CBP, Lipid Profile, ESR, LFT and other tests included in the package. For CUE and Creatinine tests you will provide a urine sample.

For the abdominal ultrasound, you must avoid eating the night prior to the test and leave any jewellery at home. A 2d echo is also an ultrasound procedure requiring similar precautions.
The package also includes a chest x-ray and an ECG – for the ECG it is best to avoid usage of moisturisers or sunscreen on the body and jewellery must be removed. For the x-ray similar protocols as above must be followed.

A bone mineral density test is similar to an x-ray and the same precautions will suffice.
For the brain CT scan, the precautions are the same as the x-ray.

As part of the whole body health check-up for women you will need to provide a pap smear for which it is advisable to abstain from intercourse the previous night and avoid usage of a vaginal cream, gel etc., also scheduling a pap smear must be avoided during a menstrual cycle. Also included for women is a mammogram is an x-ray of the breasts and it is best to schedule one right after your menstrual cycle. It is best to avoid sprays, creams and gels on the breasts prior to the mammogram.

Typically, a whole-body health check-up can be concluded in a day but will require careful scheduling based on your monthly cycle for women.

What tests are carried out, as part of the Whole Body Health Check-up?

LABORATORY TESTS

  • Complete Blood Picture with Platelet Count
  • Complete Urine Examination (CUE)
  • Erythrocyte Sedimentation Rate  (ESR)
  • Glucose, Fasting (FBS)
  • Glycosylated Hb (HbA1C)
  • HBsAg
  • Lipid Profile
  • Albumin Serum
  • Alkaline Phosphatase
  • Bilirubin (Total, Direct and Indirect) Serum
  • Gamma GT
  • Globulin Serum
  • Protein A/G Ratio Serum
  • Protein Total Serum
  • SGOT
  • SGPT
  • Calcium
  • Creatinine, Serum
  • Urea Serum
  • Uric Acid
  • Pap smear (For Female)
  • PSA (For Male)
  • Thyroid Profile (T3 T4 TSH)

RADIOLOGY & IMAGING TESTS

  • CT Brain
  • USG, Whole Abdomen & Pelvis
  • X-Ray Chest PA
  • BMD - Spine

CARDIOLOGY TESTS

  • 2D Echo
  • ECG

REPORT REVIEW

  • Physician Consultation

Important

Experts Advice: Once every 12 month
Avoid eating the night prior to the test
advised for all working adults and elderly individuals
Leave any jewellery at home

Time For All Tests
Half a Day, Depending on the clinic’s state

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Designed to diagnose and give your doctor an in-depth understanding of the functioning of your various organs and their present state.

item.title: Heart Check-up
item.dc:creator: lucidadmin
item.content:encoded:
the exact working of your heart and possible ailments of the cardiac system.

What is included

  • 11 Lab Tests
  • 1 Radiology Tests
  • 3 Cardiology Test
  • Physician Consultation

What is a Basic Heart Check-up?
A basic heart check-up is designed to help your doctor determine the exact working of your heart and possible ailments of the cardiac system. A comprehensive set of tests determine any abnormalities and can help in devising an appropriate treatment plan. Basic heart check-up gives your cardiologist an overall understanding of the functioning of your heart and possible cardiac complications that may arise in future.

Who is advised to undergo a Basic Heart Check-up?
A basic heart check is advised for all working adults and elderly individuals – across all age groups at least once in a year. This keeps you well informed of any short or long-term cardiac health issues and allows for preventive care before any of them can become serious and threatening.

Preparing for a Basic Heart Check-up
For the basic heart check-up you will be required to give a sample of blood and urine. The blood samples must be provided on an empty stomach. The blood sample will be used for CBP, Lipid Profile, ESR, LFT and other tests included in the package. For CUE and Creatinine tests you will provide a urine sample.

For the abdominal ultrasound, you must avoid eating the night prior to the test and leave any jewellery at home. A 2d echo is also an ultrasound procedure requiring similar precautions.
The package also includes a chest x-ray and an ECG – for the ECG it is best to avoid usage of moisturisers or sunscreen on the body and jewellery must be removed. For the x-ray similar protocols as above must be followed.

For the TMT stress test, it is best to avoid eating prior to the test, talk to your doctor about the medications you will need to take.

Typically, a basic heart check-up can be concluded in half a day.

LABORATORY TESTS

  • Complete Blood Picture with Platelet Count
  • Complete Urine Examination (CUE)
  • Erythrocyte Sedimentation Rate  (ESR)
  • Glucose, Fasting (FBS)
  • Glycosylated Hb (HbA1C)
  • High Sensitivity - CRP (HS-CRP)
  • Lipid Profile
  • SGOT
  • Creatinine, Serum
  • Urea
  • Uric Acid

RADIOLOGY & IMAGING TESTS

  • X-Ray Chest PA

CARDIOLOGY TESTS

  • 2D Echo
  • ECG
  • TMT

REPORT REVIEW

  • Cardiologist Consultation

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: A comprehensive set of tests to determine any abnormalities and help in devising an appropriate treatment plan
